posts.name: Ian McTavish
posts.cooked: Does anyone have good step by step directions for creating a repository in VSCode for the first time and another set of directions for setting up a program using an existing repository. We aren’t allowed to meet in person for the first three weeks and need some help with this!

posts.name: Oliver
posts.cooked:
If you are looking for software to make the instructions, Windows 10 has a built-in program called Steps Recorder that you can use for it. When ever you click it takes a screenshot with your mouse highlighted and I think you can export to PDF.

Read your post again and realized that this is not what you asked for. This is probably what you are looking for

link_counts.title: Working with GitHub in Visual Studio Code

posts.name: Liam Fruzyna
posts.cooked:
GitHub desktop is also a very good option for beginners.

Here are our instructions for using it.

link_counts.title: GitHub Desktop Cheat Sheet (2021) - Google Docs
GitHub Desktop | Simple collaboration from your desktop

posts.name: gartaud
posts.cooked:
Have you looked at Git Version Control Introduction — FIRST Robotics Competition documentation (wpilib.org) ? It could be clearer, but it’s a start.

An important point is that, as explained on page linked above, you need to install Git independently from VS Code as VS Code includes a Git UI that requires Git to be present.

Also be aware that you will need to set the user name and user email before you can push anything back to the repository from VS Code. One way to do so it via:

git config --global user.name “Your Name” git config --global user.email “ youremail@yourdomain.com ”

(where Your Name should be your GitHub login and youremail@yourdomain.com the email you used to register on GitHub)

You may also find that short video helpful: Version control in Visual Studio Code

link_counts.title: Git Version Control Introduction — FIRST Robotics Competition documentation
Version control in Visual Studio Code

posts.name: Ian McTavish
posts.cooked: Thanks, I have used GitHub for years but I still find it frustrating to teach students how to use it.

posts.name: UnofficialForth
posts.cooked:
Creating a New Robot Project and Repo

Create the new project in VS code. Save in a reasonable location (I keep a folder on Desktop labeled Repos).

Create the new project in VS code. Save in a reasonable location (I keep a folder on Desktop labeled Repos).

Download Git on your computer.

Download Git on your computer.

Open the GitBash terminal

Open the GitBash terminal

Navigate to the location of your project folder. In GitBash, use commands cd to change your directory. In my case, I would use: cd Desktop/Repos/[NameOfMyProject]

Navigate to the location of your project folder. In GitBash, use commands cd to change your directory. In my case, I would use: cd Desktop/Repos/[NameOfMyProject]

Use git init to initialize a new repo git init

Use git init to initialize a new repo git init

Use git add * to add all files to the repository. git add *

Use git add * to add all files to the repository. git add *

Commit these changes: git commit -m "Create Robot Project"

Commit these changes: git commit -m "Create Robot Project"

Create a new repo on github to house the remote repo

Create a new repo on github to house the remote repo

Use the following commands to push the repo to the remote. You may be asked to log in with a personal access token. Learn about them here git remote add origin [url of your github repo] git branch -M main git push -u origin main

Use the following commands to push the repo to the remote. You may be asked to log in with a personal access token. Learn about them here git remote add origin [url of your github repo] git branch -M main git push -u origin main

Cloning a Repo for Others to Use

Navigate to github and make sure the new user has access to the repo

Navigate to github and make sure the new user has access to the repo

Copy the url of the repository

Copy the url of the repository

Use GitBash to navigate to an appropriate folder you wish to place the repository. Again, I’ll assume it’s a folder on the Desktop called Repos: cd Desktop/Repos

Use GitBash to navigate to an appropriate folder you wish to place the repository. Again, I’ll assume it’s a folder on the Desktop called Repos: cd Desktop/Repos

Use git clone to clone the repo git clone [repo URL]

Use git clone to clone the repo git clone [repo URL]

Open the file from VSCode

Open the file from VSCode

Other Resources: Git Cheat Sheet - Educational Edition Git Cheat Sheet - Atlassian

Let me know if you need clarification on any of the above or if you need further instructions on adding, commiting, pushing, pulling, or using branches.

link_counts.title: Git cheat sheet | Atlassian Git Tutorial
Creating a personal access token - GitHub Docs

posts.name: Ian McTavish
posts.cooked: This is great, my student was able to set up our code on GitHub easily. Thanks!

posts.name: UnofficialForth
posts.cooked:
Ian_McTavish:

Thanks, I have used GitHub for years but I still find it frustrating to teach students how to use it.

If you’re teaching github to others frequently, I highly suggest reading the below book. Keep a copy around for reference. It’s worth the ~$20 dollars on amazon . (Cheaper versions are found here used, but I’ve never used thrifty books before.)

Also, read this article How to Write a Git Commit Message and make a shorten 7-10 page power point on it. It’s very beneficial as well.

link_counts.title: How to Write a Git Commit Message
Version Control with Git: Powerful tools and techniques for collaborative software development: Loeliger, Jon, McCullough, Matthew: 9781449316389: Amazon.com: Books
